Haas]] || 2006âpresent |- |} ===Formation, planning and construction=== In 1958 a study commissioned by the [[Michigan Legislature]] demonstrated a need for a four-year college in the [[Grand Rapids, Michigan|Grand Rapids]] area, Michigan's second largest metropolitan region. Local businessman [[L. William Seidman|Bill Seidman]] created a committee to study the report and spearhead the planning and promotion to create such an institution. In the following year the Michigan Legislature established the college. A naming contest was held, and out of 2500 submissions, "Grand Valley State College" was chosen. Private donations, including $350,000 to purchase land and $1,000,000 for construction, were secured from 5,000 individuals, organizations, and business throughout [[West Michigan]]. In 1961, the Grand Valley State College Board of Control chose a {{convert|876|acre|km2|adj=on}} site in [[Ottawa County, Michigan|Ottawa County]] near the [[Grand River (Michigan)|Grand River]] for the new campus, and construction of academic buildings began the following year.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/05/bill_seidman_remembered_as_man.html|title=Bill Seidman remembered as man who embraced family, education, banking and his Grand Rapids roots|date=May 14, 2009|publisher=The Grand Rapids Press|accessdate=5 January 2010|location=Grand Rapids, MI}} {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; font-size: 90%; line-height: 1.4em;" width="250px" id="Enrollment_of_Grand_Valley_State_Univerity" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background:#0067A6" | '''University Enrollment''' |- |width="70%"|'''Year''' |width="30%"|'''Enrollment''' |- | colspan="2" |
|- | 1963 | 225 |- | 1965 | 1,144 |- | 1970 | 3,301 |- | 1975 | 7,340 |- | 1980 | 6,984 |- | 1985 | 7,667 |- | 1990 | 11,726 |- | 1995 | 13,887 |- | 2000 | 18,579 |- | 2005 | 22,565 |- | 2010 | 24,541 |- |2011 | 24,662 |} ===Early years=== Grand Valley State College accepted its first class of 226 students in 1963 and held its first graduation of 138 students on June 18, 1967. The middle-late 1960s saw the addition of the first dormitories and construction of new academic buildings, including the Zumberge Library, named for the University's first President [[James Zumberge]]. In 1969, the ''Grand Valley Lanthorn'' printed an issue containing several vulgarities and obscenities. After complaints from some at Grand Valley State College and the surrounding communities, the [[Ottawa County, Michigan]], sheriff arrested the editor, and the prosecutor closed down the newspaper office. The university, then a co-ed college, sued the sheriff and prosecutor for closing the Lanthorn offices. Eventually, Michigan's Attorney General settled the case out of court, ruling in favor of Grand Valley State College.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/anniversary/history-colleges-history-1964-1969--26.htm|title=IV. The Arrival of Arend Lubbers|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=23 July 2010}} During the 1970s Grand Valley used a multiple college concept: "College of Arts and Sciences", "Thomas Jefferson College", "William James College", "Seidman College of Business", and "College IV". Former Michigan Governor [[William Milliken]] signed into law for the name to be changed to Grand Valley State Colleges in 1973. However the "s" was dropped and the name was reverted back to Grand Valley State College in 1983 when the academic programs were reorganized into divisions. ===Continued growth=== In 1987 the Michigan Legislature passed a law renaming the college to "Grand Valley State University."{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(ypntgp2yhhg4u0mfyrizce45))/mileg.aspx?page=getObject&objectName=mcl-390-861|title=Act 21 of 1963|publisher=2009 Legislative Council, State of Michigan|accessdate=15 September 2010}} The 1980s and 1990s saw addition of satellite campuses or centers in downtown Grand Rapids, Muskegon, Holland and Traverse City. In 2004, the Board of Control reorganized the University structure again into a college system consisting of College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, College of Interdisciplinary Studies, College of Community and Public Service, College of Education, College of Health Professions, [[Kirkhof College of Nursing]], Seidman College of Business, and Seymour and Esther Padnos College of Engineering and Computing. The fall semester of 2010 began a year-long celebration of the university's first 50 years of history and change. Grand Valley completed its first 50 years with a comprehensive campaign that raised almost $100 million from over 17,000 donors, making it the university's largest campaign to date. Money raised from the campaign has helped fund many new construction projects on campus, including the Mary Idema Pew Library and L. William Seidman Center.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mibiz.com/news/education/18162-gvsu-announces-totals-for-record-setting-campaign.html|title=GVSU Announces Totals for Record Setting Campaign|publisher=Michigan Business News and Information|accessdate=12 October 2011}} ==Campuses== [[File:Cook Carillon Tower.JPG|thumb|[[Cook Carillon Tower]] at Grand Valley State University-Allendale campus]] Grand Valley has three campuses: the main campus in Allendale and two satellite campuses in the surrounding area. Smaller centers in Muskegon and Traverse City also exist. The [[Interurban Transit Partnership]] operates several ''The Rapid'' bus routes under contract with the university. The public can ride these buses by paying the fare, but rides are free to Grand Valley students, faculty and staff on all Rapid routes with a valid I.D. card.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/bus/index.cfm?id=58363307-A68A-0616-9725CE578F9B5F08|title=Grand Valley State University Shuttle Services|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=23 April 2010}} ===Allendale campus=== [[File:GVSU Lake Michigan Hall.JPG|thumb|One of GVSU's first buildings and part of the Great Lakes Complex -Lake Michigan Hall.]] The University's main and original campus in Allendale is the location of most of the university's programs. The Allendale campus is composed of 1,280 [[acre]]s perched above the [[Grand River (Michigan)|Grand River]] next to a system of [[ravine]]s and is divided into two areas, north and south campus, separated in the middle by West Campus Drive.{{cite web |url=http://www.gvsu.edu/maps.htm |title=Driving Directions, Maps, and Parking Information |publisher=Grand Valley State University |work= |accessdate=16 September 2010}} State highway [[M-45 (Michigan highway)|M-45]] links the campus in suburban Allendale to [[U.S. Route 31 in Michigan|US Highway 31]]/[[Lake Michigan]] to the west and [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]] to the east. [[Lubbers Stadium]], the [[GVSU Fieldhouse]] and all other athletic facilities for the school's 19 varsity sports are also located on the Allendale campus. The campus is dotted with many sculptures including Dale Eldred, Joseph Kinnebrew and [[James Clover]]. Academic facilities on the Allendale campus include: 122 classrooms, 144 research laboratories, 20 lab prep rooms, 21 computer labs, and the Zumberge Library. ===Robert C. Pew Grand Rapids campus=== [[File:GVSU Cook Devos.jpg|thumb|GVSU Cook-Devos Center for Health Sciences, part of the Pew campus in downtown Grand Rapids]] The {{convert|33|acre|m2|adj=on}} Robert C. Pew Grand Rapids Campus is located in the heart of downtown Grand Rapids and is also located on the banks of the Grand River. Kennedy Hall of Engineering, [[Peter F. Secchia]] Hall (housing), Winter Hall (housing), and the Van Andel Global Trade Center. These facilities include 57 classrooms, 78 research laboratories, 23 lab prep rooms, 11 computer labs, and the [[Steelcase]] library. '''Medical mile''' The Cook-DeVos Center for Health Sciences, which opened in 2003, is at capacity and discussions about constructing an additional health science building nearby are underway.{{cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2011/11/gvsu_seeks_to_expand_on_medica.html|title=GVSU seeks to expand on Medical Mile in Grand Rapids|last=Reister|first=Cami|date=November 03, 2011|work=The Grand Rapids Press|accessdate=3 November 2011}} ===Meijer campus in Holland=== The Meijer Campus, located just outside downtown Holland, was opened in 1998 and was named for the [[Meijer]] Family for their generous donation of land. The campus houses continuing education programs in {{convert|30693|sqft|m2}} of building space and contains 12 classrooms, 2 conference rooms, 3 labs and 11 offices.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/operations/index.cfm?id=9DBB6734-B04A-2D93-659380AC67C5A302|title=Holland Meijer Campus|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=8 September 2010}} ===Muskegon centers=== GVSU has three locations in Muskegon: *James L. The center offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in education, social work, and liberal studies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/learn/traverse/program-information-50.htm|title=Traverse City - Program Information|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=15 September 2010}} ==Organization and administration== [[File:GVSU Student Services Building.JPG|thumb|Student Services Building at Grand Valley State University-Allendale campus]] ===Funding and financial=== GVSU's general fund budget is $265.9 million, of which $198.5 million is from tuition, and $64 million is from state appropriations. As of fall 2010, Grand Valley's amount of university-based student financial aid was $23.1 million. Also, during the 2009â2010 academic year, full time dependent students received an average award of $9,050 totaling more than $200 million in total assistance including $55 million of that in scholarships, grants, and employment.{{cite web |url=http://www.gvsu.edu/financialaid/index.cfm?id=F6C777FA-B9DB-749D-6328B043619C8068 |title=Prospective Freshmen - Financial Aid |publisher=Grand Valley State University |work= |accessdate=17 September 2010}} === Public safety === The Department of Public Safety provides law enforcement services for the Allendale Campus. While the department is self-empowered to enforce its jurisdiction, officers are also deputized by the [[Ottawa County, Michigan|Ottawa County]] [[Sheriff]]'s Department. Because [[Allendale Charter Township, Michigan|Allendale]] doesn't have its own police department, the Grand Valley State University Police can handle cases anywhere in Ottawa County, mainly in Allendale and the area surrounding the campus. The department handles other security issues, such as parking and driving violations, community policing, and lost and found. Allendale's volunteer fire department serves the campus. The Department of Public Safety also employs several students who assist the department by performing a variety of clerical and security based duties and services.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/publicsafety/index.cfm?id=FDE17056-A541-D77A-DABF4C832D6A82E4|title=GVSU Public Safety, About our Department|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=5 March 2010}} The Pew Campus Security and Regional Centers is an entity distinct from the Department of Public safety, and handles security and public safety issues for the Grand Rapids Pew Campus and all Regional Centers including the Holland (MI) Meijer Campus, the Muskegon (MI) campus and the Traverse City (MI) campus. This department is not sworn or certified and relies on the Grand Rapids Police Department and other local law enforcement agencies for official law enforcement when necessary.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/pewsecurity/index.cfm?id=6666FEEC-B4C6-4BA8-072B50AABD29E9F0|title=Pew Campus Security|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=5 March 2010}} ==Academics== ===Profile=== Grand Valley State University offers over 200 areas of study, including 81 undergraduate majors and 29 graduate programs that include 74 graduate emphases and certificate programs{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/acad-index.htm|title=Academic Programs|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=9 April 2010}} at the certificate, [[bachelor's]], post-bachelor's, [[master's]], post-master's, and [[doctoral]] levels.{{Cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/GrandValleyStateUniversity.aspx|title=Grand Valley State University|publisher=Princeton Review|accessdate=9 April 2010}} Grand Valley's student body consists of 21,236 undergraduates and 3,426 graduate students across all campuses and centers with the majority being on the Allendale campus (as of Fall 2011). The fall 2011 incoming freshman undergraduate class of 3,927 students, represented all 83 Michigan counties, 23 states, and 18 countries. 3,291 freshman chose to live on-campus in fall 2011, while 636 chose to live off-campus.{{Cite web|url= http://www.gvsu.edu/cms3/assets/056C59A0-C977-F1F7-E4201CB81AB04E47/profile-ftiacf2011.pdf|title=Profile of First-Time-In-Any-College (FTIAC) Students|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=12 October 2011}} GVSU's undergraduate admissions are classified as "more selective" by [[US News & World Report]] as Grand Valley admitted 69% of applicants for the 2008â2009 school year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.meritaid.com/meritScholarships/Grand-Valley-State-University-170082|title=Grand Valley State University Scholarships|publisher=MeritAid.com|accessdate=15 September 2010}} The fall 2011 freshman class entered Grand Valley with an average high school GPA of a 3.51 and an average ACT composite score of a 24. DeVos Center on GVSU-Pew campus]] During the two years prior to October 2009 university researchers engaged in over 186 research projects funded by more than $32.7 million in grants. Grand Valley's [[Annis Water Resources Institute]] conducts research on water resources, including: ecosystem structure and function, contaminants and toxicology, hydrology, land use, watershed, stream, and wetland ecology, water quality, and basic and applied limnology. GVSU's [[Michigan Alternative and Renewable Energy Center]] (MAREC) recently received funding for its $3.7 million Lake Michigan Offshore Wind Assessment Project to test wind energy on [[Lake Michigan]]. The research should take three years as a floating buoy will be used and moved to collect data from different locations on the lake.{{cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/muskegon/index.ssf/2010/12/buoy_to_test_wind_energy_six_m.html |title=Buoy to test wind energy six miles off Muskegon shoreline enters Lake Michigan next spring |publisher=Muskegon Chronicle |work= |accessdate=18 March 2011}} ===Accreditation=== Grand Valley as an institution is accredited by [[The Higher Learning Commission]] of the [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]].{{Cite web|url=http://catalog.gvsu.edu/content.php?catoid=2&navoid=131|title=Some Facts about Grand Valley|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=15 September 2010}} Grand Valley also has baccalaureate program accreditation with [[AACSB]], [[ABET]], [[American Physical Therapy Association|APTA]], [[Council on Social Work Education|CSWE]], [[NASAD]], [[National Association of Schools of Music|NASM]], [[NCATE]], and [[National League for Nursing|NLN]]. ===GVSU and [[Michigan State University|MSU]] partnerships=== The [[Michigan State University College of Human Medicine]] maintains the Secchia Center, a medical campus in downtown Grand Rapids.{{cite web|url=http://www.fox17online.com/news/fox17-msu-medical-school,0,4347272.story|title=MSU Medical College Dedicated In Grand Rapids|date=September 10, 2010|publisher=FOX17|accessdate=4 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.healthteam.msu.edu/medicine/meded/commcampus.htm#grandrapids|title=Grand Rapids Community Campus|publisher=Michigan State University|accessdate=3 March 2011}} Along with GVSU and two Grand Rapids hospitals, it is a founding member of the Grand Rapids Medical Education Partners. This partnership allows "educational opportunities for residents, fellows, practicing physicians, physician's assistants, nurses and students in other health professions."{{cite web|url=http://grmep.org/about/index.html|title=About|publisher=Grand Rapids Medical Education Partners|accessdate=3 March 2011}} The Early Assurance Program reserves spaces in MSU's medical program for top-performing GVSU pre-medical graduates. One of the goals of the program is to select first-generation college students, students from underprivileged areas, and/or students who have expressed a desire to work in medical specialties that are in high demand. Students entering the program must agree to work in under-served areas after completion of their medical degrees. The first group of six students entered this program during the fall 2010 semester.{{cite web|url=http://www.woodtv.com/dpp/news/education/GVSU_MSU_med_program_admits_first_class|title=GVSU-MSU med program admits first class|last=Tagliavia|first=Tony|date=18 Jun 2009|publisher=woodtv.com|accessdate=3 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://news.msu.edu/story/6492/|title=First group of GVSU students selected for MSU medical school admission|last=Kelley|first=Geri|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=Michigan State University|accessdate=3 March 2011}} The two universities have announced a joint program specializing in [[clinical trial]] management, aimed at providing the necessary foundations for carrying out clinical drug trials in West Michigan. It is an [[E-learning|online]] certificate program, and was started due to requests from local drug trial companies. The program is set to begin for the fall semester of 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/gvnow/index.htm?articleId=A90EF8B3-CC72-89B7-3B1104481B9A413C&CFID=16157737&CFTOKEN=60736508|title=Grand Valley and MSU announce health care partnerships|date=September 14, 2010|work=GVNow|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=3 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2010/09/michigan_state_grand_valley_st.html|title=Michigan State, Grand Valley State extend partnership in Grand Rapids|last=Sanchez|first=Mark|date=September 13, 2010|work=Business Review West Michigan|accessdate=3 March 2011}} ==University libraries== The mission of the Grand Valley State University libraries is to "enrich the educational mission of the university by advancing intellectual growth and discovery. Through the acquisition, application, dissemination, and preservation of knowledge we strive to serve the community, the state, the nation, and the world."{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/mission-values-strategic-plan-141.htm|title=Mission, Values & Strategic Plan|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=9 April 2010}} [[File:James H Zumberge Library.JPG|right|thumb|James H. Zumberge Library on GVSU-Allendale Campus]] ===Library locations=== Each libraryâs collection is tailored to its location and the programs it serves, with daily deliveries between sites.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/hours-locations-79.htm|title=Hours & Locations|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=9 April 2010}} *Zumberge Library (Allendale) *Steelcase Library (Grand Rapids) *Frey Foundation Learning Center (Grand Rapids) ===Library services=== The University libraries offer opportunities for research, collaboration, and individual study. Collectively, the libraries subscribe to over 53,000 print and electronic journals. They also house more than 506,000 books in print and more than 507,000 electronic books. ===Collections=== ;Government resources and maps Grand Valley is a recipient of United States government documents and currently receives 44% of the documents distributed by the [[Federal Depository Library Program]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/govdoc/|title=Government Resources and Maps - GVSU Libraries|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=17 June 2010}} ;Curriculum Materials Library (CML) The Curriculum Materials Library in the DeVos Center downtown houses instructional materials for preschool through grade twelve and provide spaces where education majors can preview resources, develop lesson plans, create media for the classroom, and try out teaching aides.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/cml/|title=Curriculum Materials Library|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=17 June 2010}} ;Special Collections & University Archives Seidman House on the Allendale Campus houses the University Archives, which include extensive collections of rare books and Michigan novels, the Harvey Lemmen Collection on [[Abraham Lincoln]] and the [[American Civil War]], the Dorothy A. Johnson Philanthropy Center Special Collections, and the papers of acclaimed Michigan author [[Jim Harrison]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/specialcollections/seidman-house-allendale-campus-4.htm|title=Special Collections & University Archives|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=17 June 2010}} ;Digital Collections The Digital Collections database contains a selection of photographs, correspondence, diaries, interviews, and publications from the holdings of the Librariesâ Special Collections & University Archives, and other University entities.{{Cite web|url=http://gvsu.cdmhost.com/gvpages/gvhome.php|title=Digital Collections|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=17 June 2010}} ===New Allendale campus library=== Grand Valley is moving forward with plans to build a new library on the Allendale campus. The new $70 million, {{convert|140000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility is planned to hold 150,000 books. It will also have an automated storage and retrieval system capable of handling 600,000 volumes. The library will be named the Mary Idema Pew Library Learning and Information Commons, after the late Mary Idema Pew.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2010/02/gvsu_works_to_move_ahead_with.html|title=GVSU works to move ahead with $70 million library without state funds|last=Murray|first=Dave |date=February 5, 2010|publisher=The Grand Rapids Press|accessdate=7 May 2010}} Construction began in May 2011 and is planned to finish in the spring of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/library/newbuilding/timeline-3.htm|title=Timeline - Mary Idema Pew Library - Grand Valley State University|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=November 22, 2011}} The [[U.S. Department of Energy]] has announced that GVSU's new library will be amongst $21 million in technical assistance projects to improve energy use in commercial buildings. The library will be one of only 24 projects in the United States receiving the assistantships that will be funded by the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]].{{cite web |url=http://www.energy.gov/news/9838.htm |title= Secretary Chu Announces Nearly $21 Million in Technical Assistance Projects to Improve Energy Use in Commercial Buildings |publisher=U.S. Department of Energy |work= |accessdate= 2 December 2010}} ==Athletics== {{Main|Grand Valley State Lakers}} {{See also|Grand Valley State Lakers football}} The Grand Valley State Lakers are the intercollegiate athletic teams of Grand Valley State University.{{Cite web| title = Quick Facts About Grand Valley | work = Grand Valley State University web site| publisher = Grand Valley State University | url = http://www.gvsu.edu/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.aboutgvsu | accessdate = February 23, 2010}} The GVSU Lakers compete at the [[Division II (NCAA)|NCAA Division II]] level and are members of the [[Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference]] (GLIAC). Grand Valley's varsity athletic teams have won nine national championships in five sports and have been national runners-up thirteen times in eight sports. GVSU has also won the prestigious National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics [[NACDA Director's Cup|(NACDA) Directors' Cup]] for NCAA Division II schools in 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, and 2011 after finishing second in 2002 and 2003.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nacda.com/directorscup/nacda-directorscup-previous-scoring.html|title=NACDA Directors Cup|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=24 July 2011}} The cup is awarded to the top athletic programs based on overall team national finishes. Grand Valley is the first college east of the Mississippi River to win the Director's Cup for NCAA Division II. ===Mascot=== The official mascot of Grand Valley State is [[Louie the Laker]]. ===Fight song=== "[[Grand_Valley_State_Lakers#Fight_song|GVSU Victory!]]" which is sometimes referred to as "Grand Valley Victory" is the fight song for the Grand Valley State University Lakers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/marchingband/history-9.htm|title=History of the Band Program at Grand Valley State University|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=9 April 2010}} ==Arts== [[File:Beckering Family Carillon Tower.jpg|thumb|Beckering Family Carillon Tower GVSU-Pew Campus]] === Fine arts === GVSU has a [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]] (NASAD) accredited art program,{{Cite web|url=http://nasad.arts-accredit.org/index.jsp?page=Member+Lists&memberId=de162ef90cd24c42001c653c0d9a51b9|title=Member list|publisher=National Association of Schools of Art and Design|accessdate=5 May 2010}} including emphases in [[illustration]], [[graphic design]], [[ceramics]], [[printmaking]], [[painting]], [[visual studies]], and [[sculpture]]. Art students attend classes at the Calder Art Center, named for contemporary artist [[Alexander Calder]]. The building includes exhibition space under the name of the Stuart & Barbara Padnos Art Gallery. Admission into the GVSU art program requires an initial review of the potential student's work. Admitted students then undergo a series of foundation classes that properly introduce them to the formal basics of art. Passing the foundation review allows access to higher level art studies, and a choice of approaching an emphasis. Subsequent reviews may take place depending upon emphases, including both junior and senior level reviews.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/acad-view.htm?pdfId=044BA628-F9CA-2A92-B60CD265D36DFC2B|title=Art and Design, B.F.A.|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=29 June 2010}} ===Music=== ;New Music Ensemble The New Music Ensemble (NME), directed by Bill Ryan,{{Cite web|url=http://newmusicensemble.org/|title=GVSU New Music Ensamble|accessdate=5 May 2010}} has released two critically acclaimed CD's, the first a recording of [[Steve Reich]]'s [[Music for 18 Musicians]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18581891|title=Steve Reich: 'Music for 18 (Cornfed) Musicians'|date=February 3, 2008|publisher=NPR|accessdate=5 May 2010}} which appeared on the Billboard Classical Crossover chart, and the second entitled ''In C Remixed'',{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/01/01/PK2U1B60M5.DTL|title=CD review: Terry Riley, 'In C Remixed'|last=Kosman|first=Joshua |date=January 3, 2010|publisher=SFGate, Hearst Communications Inc. |accessdate=5 May 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/216586|title=One-Note Wonders|last=Walls|first=Seth Colter |date=October 1, 2009|publisher=Newsweek|accessdate=15 September 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/18/AR2009121802001.html?hpid=topnews|title=The best and worst of 2009: Classical music|date=December 20, 2009|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=5 May 2010}} a remix project of [[Terry Riley]]'s [[In C]], which featured the work of some of the top electronic composers and DJ's in the world, including [[Todd Reynolds (musician)|Todd Reynolds]], [[Michael Lowenstern]], and Pulitzer prize winner [[David Lang (composer)|David Lang]]. The NME performed at Le Poisson Rouge in New York City on November 2, 2009{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/10/arts/music/10grand.html?_r=1&ref=le_poisson_rouge|title=A Classic Minimalist Score, Played at Maximal (and Electronical) Length|last=Kozinn|first=Allan|date=November 9, 2009|publisher=The New York Times Music Review|accessdate=29 June 2010}} and previously at the 2007 [[Bang on a Can]] festival.{{Cite web|url=http://bangonacan.org/marathon/schedule/2007|title=Bang on a Can Marathon 2007 Schedule|publisher=Bang on a Can|accessdate=29 June 2010}} ;Trumpet ensemble Directed by Richard Stoelzel, Grand Valley's trumpet ensemble has been a top competitor in the [[National Trumpet Competition]] for nearly a decade, placing 1st in the ensemble division in 2006 and 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/gvnow/index.htm?articleId=C3339E69-B075-F26A-9BEDDB23CA304ADD|title=Grand Valley trumpet ensemble wins national championship|date=March 19, 2008|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=5 May 2010}} The ensemble has commissioned 4 pieces by composer [[Erik Morales]] since 2005, two of which went on to become the winning pieces, and one of which is still currently unpremiered. The trumpet ensemble has performed twice during the [[International Trumpet Guild]]'s summer conferences in 2007{{Cite web|url=http://www1.gvsu.edu/gvnow/index.cfm?articleId=01799E14-9B39-846B-CF10039D8F080B81&archiveDate=01-Nov-02|title=GVSU trumpeter wins international competition|date=June 6, 2007|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=29 June 2010}} and 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://www.messiah.edu/itg/trumpet_prelude.html|title=Trumpet Prelude and Festival of Trumpets|publisher=Messiah College|accessdate=29 June 2010}} ==Student life== The Office of Student Life at GVSU is located in the [[Kirkhof Center]] near the center of the Allendale campus. International Honorary Organization for Finance, Accounting, and Information Systems *[[Phi Sigma Pi]] - National Honor Fraternity *[[Phi Chi Theta]] - Professional CoEd Business Fraternity ===Sustainability=== [[File:GVSU Little Mac Bridge.JPG|thumb|Little Mac Bridge at Grand Valley State University-Allendale campus]] Grand Valley's Sustainable Community Development Initiative provides "Grand Valley administration, faculty, staff, students, and community stakeholders with the required skills and capabilities to become better stewards and responsible global citizens in the workforce, communities, and family life."{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/sustainability/|title=Sustainable Community Development Initiative|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=5 July 2010}} Notable programs include a [[community garden]] near the GVSU Allendale campus{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsugarden.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=section&layout=blog&id=1&Itemid=2|title=About the Garden|publisher=GVSU Community Garden|accessdate=5 July 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2010/01/25/gvsu|title=The New Sustainability U.|last=Moltz|first=David|date=January 25, 2010|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate=5 July 2010}} and a campus sustainability week in October.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/sustainability/campus-sustainability-week-2010-176.htm|title=Campus Sustainability Week 2010|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=5 July 2010}} The university has created a formal climate action plan and set a goal to reduce it's 2006 level greenhouse gas emissions 20% by 2020. The university's sustainability efforts were awarded a "A-" by the [[Campus_Carbon_Neutrality#Sustainable_Endowments_Institute_.26_the_College_Sustainability_Report_Card|Sustainable Endowments Institute]] for 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.greenreportcard.org/report-card-2011/schools/grand-valley-state-university|title=Grand Valley State University|publisher=Sustainable Endowments Institute|accessdate=3 January 2010}} Grand Valley's overall sustainability grade is the highest amongst the nine Michigan universities that were surveyed and the 28th best in the nation.{{cite web |url=http://www.greenreportcard.org/compare |title=Compare college sustainability - Green Report Card |publisher=Sustainable Endowments Institute |work= |accessdate=3 January 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.greenreportcard.org/report-card-2011/schools/search/235 |title=Report Card 2011 - Best Overall Grades |publisher=Sustainable Endowments Institute |work= |accessdate=3 January 2011}} The university is currently home to eleven Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design ([[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]]) buildings or building additions. Several more buildings including the new Mary Idema Pew Library are in construction or planning stages to be LEED certified as well.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/sustainability/leed-buildings-131.htm |title=LEED Certified Buildings at GVSU - Sustainable Community Development Initiative |publisher=Grand Valley State University |work= |accessdate=June 23, 2010}} All new construction and major renovations at GVSU must meet LEED standards required by the university. The Student Environmental Coalition or SEC, is the student-run sustainability organization on campus. The mission of the group is "Helping to engage students at Grand Valley's campus to be conscious citizens by promotion of environmental awareness."{{cite web |url=http://www2.gvsu.edu/~sec/index.html |title=GVSU Student Evironmental Coalition |publisher=GVSU SEC |work= |accessdate=4 January 2011}} Grand Valley hosted meetings relating to sustainability, including a summit in which various sustainability issues were explored by university officials and local experts in April 2010,{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2010/04/grand_valley_state_university_6.html|title=Grand Valley State University to host sustainability summit|date=April 3, 2010|publisher=The Grand Rapids Press|accessdate=5 July 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.gvsu.edu/hauenstein/index.cfm?id=999842BA-94FA-AA53-866E14924BAC9209|title=Grand Valley Summit on Sustainability|publisher=The Hauenstein Center for Presidential Studies|accessdate=5 July 2010}} and a meeting of the Michigan Great Lakes Wind Council in July 2010 to discuss offshore wind energy generation.{{Cite news|url=http://www.grandhaventribune.com/paid/300964828922857.bsp|title=GVSU hosts state wind council meeting July 20|date=July 14, 2010|work=Grand Haven Tribune|accessdate=20 July 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theoaklandpress.com/articles/2010/07/20/news/doc4c45948e2f1ab735197816.txt|title=Wind power meetings set for Grand Rapids, Dearborn|date=July 20, 2010|publisher=The Oakland Press|accessdate=16 September 2010}} ===Media=== GVSU has a variety of media outlets offered to its campuses. The ''[[Grand Valley Lanthorn]]'' is the student-run newspaper, published on Mondays and Thursdays during the academic year. Copies of the paper are free and available at both the Allendale and Grand Rapids campuses in designated newsstands and online. Until the fall of 2006, the paper was only published once per week. Currently 8,000 copies of the paper are published per issue totaling 16,000 copies per week.{{cite web |url=http://www.lanthorn.com/index.php/page/about_us |title=Grand Valley Lanthorn :: About Us |publisher=Grand Valley Lanthorn |work= |accessdate=4 January 2011}} GVSU has several electronic media outlets including three radio stations and three television stations. The university owns and operates its own [[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS) [[Public television]] station [[WGVU-TV]] in Allendale, Michigan and [[WGVU-TV|WGVK-TV]], its full time satellite station in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]]. In addition, GVSU also operates two [[National Public Radio]] (NPR) stations in [[WGVU (AM)]] and [[WGVU-FM]] with the same call letters, which feature a mixture of [[jazz]], [[blues]], and [[news]], including local and NPR programming.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wgvu.org/about/|title=About WGVU|publisher=WGVU|accessdate=5 March 2010}} [[WCKS (college radio)|WCKS]] "The Whale" is the student-run radio station, broadcasting over the internet and on a soon-to-be announced FM channel.
